question.title: Calling SearchableComboBox.getItems().remove() from the OnAction Event results in an IndexOutOfBoundsException
question.body:
I am trying to create a JavaFX project featuring multiple instances of the SearchableComboBox control from the ControlsFX library, each having the same list of options. When an option is selected in a box, it is removed from the others using the .getItems().remove() method. I store the selected value in a variable so that when a new value is chosen, the prior value can be added back to the other boxes.

While coding this I encountered two problems:

  1. The OnAction Event is triggered three times, setting the box to the intended value, then to null, then back to the intended value. I have coded a workaround by checking the value of the box to see if it is null or already matches the prior value and not running code if either is true.
  2. When .getItems().remove() is called, it generates an Index out of bounds for length Error.

The code technically works in terms of the final result. However, I would assume that the error indicates that I am not using best practice, or that something is wrong with the library.

I have tried using Platform.runLater(), but the error still is generated. I have also tested a version of the code with the base JavaFX ComboBox and neither issue occurs there. Is there a way to avoid the Index out of bounds for length error?

I have written a demo of the issue as a means of better understanding it and providing code that recreates the error.

public class HelloController {
    @FXML
    private SearchableComboBox<String> cb1;
    @FXML
    private SearchableComboBox<String> cb2;
    @FXML
    private SearchableComboBox<String> cb3;

    private ArrayList<SearchableComboBox<String>> comboBoxes;

    String strSelected1;
    String strSelected2;
    String strSelected3;

    public void initialize() {
        ArrayList<String> strsList = new ArrayList<String>();
        strsList.add("A");
        strsList.add("B");
        strsList.add("C");
        strsList.add("D");
        strsList.add("E");
        strsList.add("F");
        strsList.add("G");
        strsList.add("H");
        cb1.setItems(FXCollections.observableList((ArrayList<String>) strsList.clone()));
        cb2.setItems(FXCollections.observableList((ArrayList<String>) strsList.clone()));
        cb3.setItems(FXCollections.observableList((ArrayList<String>) strsList.clone()));
        comboBoxes = new ArrayList<SearchableComboBox<String>>();
        comboBoxes.add(cb1);
        comboBoxes.add(cb2);
        comboBoxes.add(cb3);
    }

    // get selected value from combobox, remove from other two comboboxes
    // re-add previously selected value to combobox
    private void readdPreviousAndRemoveSelected(SearchableComboBox<String> cbSelected, String priorSelection) {
        System.out.println("Selected Value: " + cbSelected.getValue());
        for (SearchableComboBox<String> cb: comboBoxes) {
            if (cb != cbSelected) {
                System.out.println("Selected Value (Other Box): " + cb.getValue());
                if (priorSelection != null) {
                    Platform.runLater(() -> {
                        System.out.println("Readd: " + priorSelection);
                        cb.getItems().add(priorSelection);
                    });
                }
                if (cbSelected.getValue() != null)  {
                    Platform.runLater(() -> {
                        System.out.println("Remove: " + cbSelected.getValue());
                        cb.getItems().remove(cbSelected.getValue());
                    });
                }
                System.out.println("Size (Other Box): " + cb.getItems().size());
            }
        }
    }

    @FXML
    private void OnCB1Selected() {
        System.out.println("CB1 OnAction: Str: " + strSelected1 + " Box: " + cb1.getValue());
        // if statement prevents code from running if value is null or already set
        // thus, it prevents the additional calls to the method from doing much
        if (cb1.getValue() != null && !Objects.equals(cb1.getValue(), strSelected1)) {
            readdPreviousAndRemoveSelected(cb1, strSelected1);
            strSelected1 = cb1.getValue();
        }
        System.out.println("End CB1: STR: " + strSelected1 + " Box: " + cb1.getValue());
    }

    @FXML
    private void OnCB2Selected() {
        System.out.println("CB2 OnAction: Str: " + strSelected2 + " Box: " + cb2.getValue());
        // if statement prevents code from running if value is null or already set
        // thus, it prevents the additional calls to the method from doing much
        if (cb2.getValue() != null && !Objects.equals(cb2.getValue(), strSelected2)) {
            readdPreviousAndRemoveSelected(cb2, strSelected2);
            strSelected2 = cb2.getValue();
        }
        System.out.println("End CB2: STR: " + strSelected2 + " Box: " + cb2.getValue());
    }

    @FXML
    private void OnCB3Selected() {
        System.out.println("CB3 OnAction: Str: " + strSelected3 + " Box: " + cb3.getValue());
        // if statement prevents code from running if value is null or already set
        // thus, it prevents the additional calls to the method from doing much
        if (cb3.getValue() != null && !Objects.equals(cb3.getValue(), strSelected3)) {
            readdPreviousAndRemoveSelected(cb3, strSelected3);
            strSelected3 = cb3.getValue();
        }
        System.out.println("End CB3: STR: " + strSelected3 + " Box: " + cb3.getValue());
    }
}

Here is the accompanying fxml:

<VBox alignment="CENTER" prefHeight="300.0" prefWidth="300.0" spacing="20.0" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/null" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" fx:controller="dvcom.demo.multicombobox.HelloController">
    <padding>
        <Insets bottom="20.0" left="20.0" right="20.0" top="20.0" />
    </padding>
   <children>
      <SearchableComboBox fx:id="cb1" onAction="#OnCB1Selected" />
      <SearchableComboBox fx:id="cb2" onAction="#OnCB2Selected" />
      <SearchableComboBox fx:id="cb3" onAction="#OnCB3Selected" />
   </children>
</VBox>

Thank you for your time and attention.

question_comments.body: Here is how to reduce your code. I used ComboBox. You can test different versions of Searchable ComboBox to see if one does not have this bug. Add your System.out.println statements back to make sure it's working as you expect. gist.github.com/sedj601/abefc00be5f8beda29b7a5dceb4343ab

I simplified your program to just two Searchable Combo Boxes and simplified your remove code (Yours is overly complicated IMO). I got the same error. I then took that simplified code and replaced the Searchable Combo Boxes with JavaFX Combo Boxes, and it worked without any problems. Looks like a bug, maybe.
Instead of using the FXML onAction attribute, you might add a listener to the valueProperty of each ComboBox in your initialize method
